verses.text: Then the king sent, and all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem were gathered to him.
verses.comment: Josiah, the king, takes initiative to gather the leaders for a solemn assembly. This is a pivotal moment showing the unity of God's people under a divinely appointed leader, foreshadowing future gatherings of the faithful (see Acts 15:6 in the New Testament).

verses.text: The king went up to the house of the LORD, and with him all the men of Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the priests, the prophets, and all the people, both small and great. He read in their hearing all the words of the book of the covenant that had been found in the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Josiah gathers all levels of society, emphasizing the communal nature of covenant renewal. The public reading of Scripture points to the importance of both the leaders’ and the community's participation in God’s covenant, anticipating liturgical practices and the role of sacred Scripture in the life of the faithful (see Neh. 8:1–8).

verses.text: The king stood by the pillar and made a covenant before the LORD, to walk after the LORD and to keep his commandments, his testimonies, and his statutes with all his heart and all his soul, to perform the words of this covenant that were written in this book. And all the people joined in the covenant.
verses.comment: Covenant renewal is central to this passage; it requires both a heart that genuinely seeks God and a public action. Josiah’s leadership serves as a model for spiritual authority, reflecting how true reform and fidelity flow from both leaders and people (see Heb. 8:10 for a new heart to keep the law in Christ’s covenant).

verses.text: The king commanded Hilkiah the high priest, the priests of the second order, and the keepers of the threshold to bring out of the temple of the LORD all the vessels that were made for Baal, for Asherah, and for all the host of heaven. He burned them outside Jerusalem in the fields of Kidron and carried their ashes to Bethel.
verses.comment: Josiah abolishes idol worship within the very temple of the LORD, cleansing God's house. The decisive action and ritual burning of pagan objects evoke the call for pure worship and foreshadow the purification of God’s people promised in the prophets (Mal. 3:1-3).

verses.text: He removed the priests whom the kings of Judah had ordained to burn incense on the high places in the cities of Judah and around Jerusalem—those also who burned incense to Baal, to the sun, the moon, the constellations, and all the host of heaven.
verses.comment: By deposing illegitimate priests and practices, Josiah defends the sanctity of God’s ordained worship. This shows the need for rightly ordered ministers and proper worship—a theme connected to Christ who fulfills and perfects worship in the New Covenant (see Heb. 7:23-28; John 4:23-24).

verses.text: He brought out the Asherah from the house of the LORD, outside Jerusalem to the brook Kidron, and burned it at the brook Kidron, and beat it to dust, and threw its dust on the graves of the common people.
verses.comment: Purging the temple and casting pagan dust on common graves suggests the utter rejection of idolatry (see Ezek. 6:5). Removing the Asherah from the LORD’s house points to the exclusive holiness required in the place of divine worship, later fulfilled in the heavenly sanctuary (Heb. 9:23-24).

verses.text: He broke down the houses of the male cult prostitutes who were in the house of the LORD, where the women wove hangings for the Asherah.
verses.comment: Eliminating immorality from the temple, Josiah restores the house of God to purity. This act illustrates the importance of chastity and the dignity of the place dedicated for worship—a value upheld in later Christian tradition (cf. Matt. 21:12-13 when Jesus purges the temple).

verses.text: He brought all the priests out of the cities of Judah, and defiled the high places where the priests had burned incense, from Geba to Beersheba. He broke down the high places of the gates that were at the entrance of the gate of Joshua the governor of the city, which were on one’s left at the gate of the city.
verses.comment: Josiah destroys unauthorized worship sites, emphasizing the one legitimate place for sacrificial worship established by God (Deut. 12:13-14). This prefigures the unity of true worship centered on God’s ordained sanctuary and points to the later understanding of the Church as the one temple of God (Eph. 2:21).

verses.text: The priests of the high places, however, did not come up to the altar of the LORD in Jerusalem, but they ate unleavened bread among their brothers.
verses.comment: The exclusion of these priests from God’s altar in Jerusalem highlights the importance of legitimate, authorized ministry—a major theme continued in the New Testament, as Christ calls and authorizes His apostles to continue His ministry (see Luke 22:19-20; John 20:21-23).

verses.text: He defiled Topheth, which is in the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, so that no one might burn his son or his daughter as an offering to Molech.
verses.comment: Josiah puts an end to child sacrifice, a gross violation of God’s law. The Valley of Hinnom (Gehenna) later becomes a symbol of final judgment, referenced by Jesus as a warning of hell (Matt. 5:22).

verses.text: He removed the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun at the entrance to the house of the LORD, by the chamber of Nathan-melech the chamberlain, which was in the precincts. And he burned the chariots of the sun with fire.
verses.comment: Josiah’s destruction of sun-worship implements demonstrates faithfulness to the LORD alone. The eradication of syncretistic practices anticipates the coming Messiah’s exclusive mediation between God and men (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: He pulled down the altars that were on the roof, the upper chamber of Ahaz, which the kings of Judah had made, as well as the altars that Manasseh had made in the two courts of the house of the LORD. He broke them in pieces and cast their dust into the brook Kidron.
verses.comment: Thoroughly demolishing the physical remnants of idolatry, Josiah’s reforms display the radical nature of true repentance. True worship is not compromised or syncretized—a key principle reinforced by Jesus’ cleansing of the temple (John 2:14-16).

verses.text: The king defiled the high places that were east of Jerusalem, to the south of the Mount of Corruption, which Solomon king of Israel had built for Ashtoreth the abomination of the Sidonians, and for Chemosh the abomination of Moab, and for Milcom the abomination of the Ammonites.
verses.comment: By tearing down what even Solomon misguidedly established, Josiah affirms that all are accountable to God, even kings. This highlights the need for continual reform and fidelity to the covenant, which finds its perfection in Christ.

verses.text: He broke in pieces the pillars and cut down the Asherim, and filled their places with human bones.
verses.comment: Desecrating pagan sites by scattering human bones rendered them ritually unclean. The thoroughness of the destruction illustrates the need for total separation from idolatry in devotion to the true God.

verses.text: Moreover, the altar at Bethel, the high place that Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who made Israel to sin, had made—even that altar with the high place he broke down, and burned the high place and crushed it to dust; and he burned the Asherah.
verses.comment: This fulfills the prophecy given at Bethel centuries earlier (see 1 Kgs. 13:2), demonstrating God's sovereignty. The destruction of rival altars points ahead to the unity that Christ accomplishes in His one body (Eph. 4:4-6).

verses.text: As Josiah turned, he saw the tombs that were there on the mountain. He sent and took the bones out of the tombs and burned them on the altar, defiling it, according to the word of the LORD that the man of God proclaimed, who had announced these things.
verses.comment: Josiah’s actions directly fulfill God’s word given by the man of God, showing both divine faithfulness to prophecy and the necessity of heeding God’s commands (cf. Matt. 5:17 – all is fulfilled in Christ).

verses.text: Then he said, 'What is this monument that I see?' The men of the city told him, 'It is the tomb of the man of God who came from Judah and proclaimed these things that you have done against the altar at Bethel.'
verses.comment: The preserved grave of the true prophet is honored. God’s faithfulness to His servants and their message is reaffirmed. Respect for tradition and true prophecy is upheld here, later mirrored as the faithful venerate the memory of God’s saints in the New Covenant.

verses.text: He said, 'Let him be; let no one move his bones.' So they left his bones undisturbed, with the bones of the prophet who came out of Samaria.
verses.comment: The protection and honoring of prophetic bones points to a respect for the bodies of the righteous, prefiguring later Christian reverence for the remains of saints and the doctrine of the resurrection of the body (see 1 Thess. 4:16).

verses.text: Josiah removed all the shrines also of the high places that were in the cities of Samaria, which the kings of Israel had made to provoke the LORD to anger. He did to them just as he had done at Bethel.
verses.comment: Josiah’s reforms extend beyond Judah to Samaria, reclaiming lands once lost. It shows the king’s zeal for universal fidelity to God's covenant—a theme later fulfilled in Christ’s commission to all nations (Matt. 28:19).

verses.text: He slaughtered all the priests of the high places who were there, on the altars, and burned human bones on them. Then he returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The severity of Josiah’s actions demonstrates the seriousness of true worship and God’s judgment on apostasy. This anticipates the judgment Christ warns of against false shepherds (John 10:12-13).

verses.text: The king commanded all the people, 'Keep the Passover to the LORD your God, as it is written in this book of the covenant.'
verses.comment: Josiah restores the proper celebration of Passover, a foundational act of remembrance and deliverance. This feast finds its completion in Christ, our true Passover Lamb (1 Cor. 5:7), especially in the memorial meal He establishes at the Last Supper.

verses.text: Surely such a Passover had not been kept since the days of the judges who judged Israel, nor throughout all the days of the kings of Israel or of the kings of Judah.
verses.comment: Josiah’s restoration is presented as a unique event, not observed with such devotion since the time of the judges. This highlights the significance of renewed covenant worship, prefiguring Christ’s inauguration of the new covenant and the central act of Christian worship.

verses.text: But in the eighteenth year of King Josiah, this Passover was kept to the LORD in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The dating of Josiah’s great Passover situates it as a climactic act of national renewal, indicating the importance of solemn feasts celebrated in the place God chooses. This sets a pattern for God’s people to gather with intention and unity.

verses.text: Moreover, Josiah put away the mediums, the necromancers, the household gods, the idols, and all the abominations that were seen in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem, that he might establish the words of the law that were written in the book that Hilkiah the priest found in the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Josiah’s reforms uproot not just public idolatry but private and occult practices as well. This comprehensive renewal demonstrates the need for holiness in all aspects of life, anticipating the fullness of law written on the heart in Christ (Jer. 31:33).

verses.text: Before him there was no king like him, who turned to the LORD with all his heart, with all his soul, and with all his might, according to all the law of Moses, nor did any like him arise after him.
verses.comment: Josiah is praised for his wholehearted devotion and adherence to God's law. His example points forward to the coming of the One who will perfectly fulfill the law—Jesus Christ (Matt. 5:17).

verses.text: Yet still the LORD did not turn from the fierceness of his great wrath, by which his anger was kindled against Judah, because of all the provocations with which Manasseh had provoked him.
verses.comment: Despite Josiah’s reforms, prior generations’ sins require judgment. This sober truth underscores that purification cannot come merely from human effort; only God's ultimate act in Christ reconciles and restores (Rom. 5:8-10).

verses.text: And the LORD said, 'I will remove Judah also out of my sight, as I have removed Israel, and I will cast off this city that I have chosen, Jerusalem, and the house of which I said, "My name shall be there."'
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s impending rejection points to the need for a new, spiritual center of worship fulfilled in Christ (see John 4:21-24), where God’s presence is not localized but universal in His people.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Josiah, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: This common formula refers readers to parallel historical records. Chronicles contains additional details about Josiah’s reign, encouraging a reverent search of all scriptural witnesses for the full story.

verses.text: In his days Pharaoh Neco king of Egypt went up to the king of Assyria to the river Euphrates. King Josiah went out to meet him, but Pharaoh Neco killed him at Megiddo as soon as he saw him.
verses.comment: Tragically, Josiah is killed in battle, highlighting both the mystery of God’s providence and man’s limitations. Even the most faithful can suffer and die, pointing to the necessity of hope in God’s ultimate deliverance, seen in Christ’s own death and resurrection.

verses.text: His servants carried him dead in a chariot from Megiddo, and brought him to Jerusalem, and buried him in his own tomb. The people of the land took Jehoahaz the son of Josiah and anointed him, and made him king in his father’s place.
verses.comment: Even after such sorrow, the rituals of burial, succession, and anointing are maintained. The continuity of the Davidic line, despite disaster, signals God’s faithfulness, culminating in the Messiah.

verses.text: Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he began to reign, and he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
verses.comment: The brief reign and lineage of Jehoahaz highlights the instability that follows Josiah’s death; family details are noted, echoing the biblical pattern of recording important genealogies for God’s plan.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, according to all that his fathers had done.
verses.comment: Jehoahaz follows the evil ways of previous kings, contrasting sharply with Josiah. The scripture continually emphasizes the need for ongoing conversion and faithfulness to God's law.

verses.text: Pharaoh Neco put him in bonds at Riblah in the land of Hamath, that he might not reign in Jerusalem, and imposed on the land a tribute of one hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
verses.comment: Foreign domination results from unfaithfulness, with the people burdened by tribute. Israel’s independence wanes under other powers, pointing out the consequences of breaking covenant fidelity.

verses.text: Pharaoh Neco made Eliakim the son of Josiah, king in place of Josiah his father, and changed his name to Jehoiakim. But he took Jehoahaz away, and he came to Egypt and died there.
verses.comment: The renaming of Eliakim signifies new foreign control, and Jehoahaz’s exile fulfills prophetic warnings. Naming underscores authority, as seen when God renames His servants to signify new missions (cf. Gen. 17:5).

verses.text: Jehoiakim gave the silver and the gold to Pharaoh, but he taxed the land to give the money according to Pharaoh’s command. He exacted the silver and gold from the people of the land, from each according to his assessment, to give it to Pharaoh Neco.
verses.comment: Economic oppression and heavy taxation befall the people under Jehoiakim, a grim result of forsaking God’s covenant. The subplot of unjust rulers would later be reversed in Christ, who bears burdens for His people (Matt. 11:29-30).

verses.text: Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zebidah the daughter of Pedaiah of Rumah.
verses.comment: Accurate details about Jehoiakim anchor the narrative in history and underline the passing succession of unfaithful kings awaiting God's true King.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, according to all that his fathers had done.
verses.comment: Jehoiakim’s evil is summed up as being continuous with his forefathers. Human failure continues to cry out for the coming of the righteous King—the Messiah—where trust is finally and fully met.
